stories.text:
I made a proof of concept using Docker Compose showing dynamic debug logging in the cloud using a structured logging framework. The PoC uses script and JSONPath to evaluate the input structured data to determine criteria for logging:

https://github.com/tersesystems/dynamic-debug-logging

I have examples of more dynamic logging stuff:

https://github.com/tersesystems/echopraxia-examples

There's a couple of other instance of dynamic logging, but it does not seem to be very well known. For example the Linux kernel:

https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/v4.11/admin-guide/dynamic-debug-howto.html

and Pixie, using Go and eBPF:

https://docs.pixielabs.ai/tutorials/custom-data/dynamic-go-logging/
stories.title: Dynamic Debug Logging

stories.text:
Just got an email and link to this update from status.heroku.com. Sounds pretty dodgy. In effect, it means I'm unable to link up a new GitHub repo to Heroku and might not be able to do any updates either.

------------

To mitigate impact from potentially compromised OAuth tokens, we will revoke over the next several hours all existing tokens from the Heroku GitHub integration. We are also preventing new OAuth tokens from being created until further notice. Your GitHub repositories will not be affected in any way by this action.

Currently running Heroku applications will not be affected, but this will prevent you from deploying your apps from GitHub through the dashboard or via automation. Some other actions in the dashboard will no longer work due to this mitigation, and you will be unable to reconnect to GitHub even though you may see warning banners about reconnecting. As a temporary workaround, you can use one of the other code deployment methods available in the following documentation:
stories.title: Heroku: Compromised OAuth Tokens for GitHub
Using SBCL Common Lisp as a Dynamic Library

stories.text:
I thought my entrepreneurial spirit and experiences trying to start businesses/build products, helping out at a University "startup course" (much imposter syndrome, yes) and my past in Project Management were gonna be enough to get a shot at a startup but I've been getting rejection after rejection.

Quick recap of my CV

- 3 years PM in Advertising. Strategy and management of the creative team

- 2 years working as Customer Support drone in Big Boring Company with very little room to move and change departments

- 1 year or so helping out at university Venture Lab where we do workshops and Pitch simulations for entrepreneurs and students (about 50-50).

- I did 2-3 projects that never took off and one app that gave me some satisfaction (someone bought it) but never even broke even. In that case I acted as a Product Manager and had 1 developer doing the work for me.

- I did CS50 from Harvard online and a Python course with MIT both on EDx, but I am not able to apply for a programmer job (which I think I would enjoy and might be a way to eventually turn into a technical PM)

I'm playing around with selenium and chromedriver building a bot that swipes on tinder based on certain parameters, but I don't feel like I could be considered for a programming job.
stories.title: Ask HN: I'm 30, how to break in Product roles at tech company/startup?
Tim Cook is right and wrong about sideloading
